en.content_html:
Chapter I. The name, purposes and address

article 01

THE ETRESMIL ASSOCIATION regulates its activities in accordance with Law 4/2008, of April 24, of the third book of the Civil Code of Catalonia, relating to legal persons; Organic Law 1/2002, of March 22, regulating the right of association, and its statutes.

article 02
  1. The ETRESMIL association aims to carry out, promote and disseminate artistic practices from collectivity to respond to the usual dynamics oriented toward the individuality of artistic practice and to ensure the maintenance and reproduction of this alternative movement of contemporary arts and a transformation of the community cultural context.
  2. The purposes of ETRESMIL —Structures of Relational Works, Social Encounters, Materialities and Liminal Imaginaries— are divided based on the association's name:

Structuring (E)

  • Develop an internal organizational structure that enables good practices of collective artistic action.
  • Transfer and reproduce these methodologies in the contemporary cultural environment.
  • Fight for the rights of the artistic collective and dignified work in the sector, focusing on the problems and needs of collective and associative cultural productions.
  • Seek a social return and effective associative functioning in its environment.
  • Use a dialogic and horizontal participation methodology to achieve a higher democratic and egalitarian index in joint artistic practice. Bringing together scientific practice —social, political...—, artistic practice, and the sociopolitical experiences of the membership and its environment.

Develop collective artistic practice through Relational Work (TR)

  • Relate the practices, disciplines and needs of the association to seek new ways of making art that question the dominant imaginary.
  • Foster the relationship between artistic production and citizens, especially in sectors it does not reach.
  • Encourage dialogic debate under equal conditions in a safe space where associated people engage with proximity and care.
  • Include emotional values within governing bodies in order to objectify discomforts and complaints coming from the membership.
  • Ensure inclusive participation from the perspective of class, culture and gender through the collective and consensual creation of external and internal diversity protocols. By protocol is meant the arrangement of a consensual drafting of a series of norms and values.

Promote Social Encounters (ES)

  • Provide a cultural meeting space among membership, friends of the association and citizens.
  • Seek a transversal nature of social encounters and not isolate the artistic practice.

Work from Materialities and Liminal Imaginaries (MIL)

  • Carry out artistic practices from collectivity through diverse materialities.
  • Promote the autonomy of fabrication and production of the association's membership and disseminate teaching about them.
  • Enable the fabrication and production of the association's materials and devices to carry out its community purposes.
  • Produce and promote collective imaginaries that work in the community cultural context.
  • Disseminate the production of imaginaries of collective practices and the association's purpose.
  • Ensure a varied and plural artistic formalization, showing the links and relationships of those who participate, as well as how they understand their context and its direction.
  • The activities and functions of the ETRESMIL entity will be developed in interrelation and collaboration among its commissions, membership, friends and the public, always maintaining a correspondence.
  • All profit motive is excluded.
  1. To achieve its purposes the association carries out the following activities:
    • Provide, present and exhibit artistic actions, installations and performances from a collective art practice that is plural and not unitary.
    • Ensure collective production within the cultural sector linked to the artists' union.
    • Carry out educational actions and offer artistic devices open to the public in public, private institutions or outside them.
    2. article 03
  2. The association's address is established in Esplugues de Llobregat and is located at Carrer Pere Galvany nº 28 local, with postal district 08950.
  3. The functions of this association are exercised mainly in Catalonia.

Chapter II. Membership of the association, rights and obligations

article 04

Potentially, all natural persons who, freely and voluntarily, have an interest in its purposes may become part of the association.

  • They must have legal capacity to act.
  • If they are minors between 14 and 18 years of age and not emancipated, they need parental consent to become full members of the association, with the right to vote in general assemblies. Even so, they may not be part of the Board of Directors.
  • Minors under 14 may acquire the status of member and exercise the rights derived from this status through legal representatives.

To join, it is necessary to send an email to the association to arrange a meeting. At this meeting, the interest of the applicant will be asked about and the particular case will be studied with the membership of the association. Among other things, it will be taken into account how the applicant learned about the association, how they relate to their environment, and their personal interest relative to individual and collective practice. The two membership options will be presented; in any case, during the next ordinary assembly a decision will be made on the request of the interested person. The decision must be unanimous. At the end of this process, the person who has applied for membership will be informed of the decision taken.

article 05

The different types of membership of the association in which one can enroll are:

  • Type 1 member: member who pays a full fee, has free access to the association's facilities.
  • Type 2 member: member who pays a reduced fee, does not have free access to the association's facilities. Access will be open during activities, meetings or by requesting access from one of the type 1 members.

Both Type 1 Member and Type 2 Member have equal voice and vote in assemblies, meetings and projects carried out within the association, as well as access to positions on the board of directors (if applicable).

A parallel type is added called Friends of ETRESMIL. It is a free modality with the option of voluntary donations to the association that allows access to direct information networks. They have access and voice at meetings and assemblies, if they request it, but their participation is not constituent of the decisions taken there nor do they have voting rights. They will only have access to the association's documentation if they request it and it is approved in Ordinary Assembly.

article 06

These are rights of the membership of the association, of Type 1 and Type 2 members:

  • Attend with voice and in a constituent manner the meetings of the General Assembly.
  • Elect or be elected to representation positions or to hold directive posts.
  • Exercise the representation conferred to them in each case.
  • Intervene in the governance and management, in the services and activities of the association, in accordance with legal and statutory rules.
  • Present to the Assembly and the Board of Directors everything they consider can contribute to making the life of the association fuller and to more effectively achieving basic social objectives.
  • Question statutory issues and conduct protocols for possible modification.
  • Request and obtain explanations about the administration and management of the Board of Directors and the association's commissions.
  • Right to speech and equal listening.
  • Have a safe space to develop issues.
  • Receive information about the association's activities.
  • Make use of the common services that the association establishes or has at its disposal.
  • Be part of commissions and create new ones.
  • Possess a copy of the statutes.
  • Consult the association's books and any relevant documentation.
  • Propose, in exceptional cases and in assembly, the exchange of payment of the fee for a specific service in-kind mediated by the entire membership in ordinary assembly.
  • Know the membership fees and their updates.
  • Right to be heard and to defense before disciplinary measures are adopted.
article 07

These are duties of the membership of the association, both Type 1 and Type 2 members:

  • Commit to the purposes of the association and actively participate to achieve them.
  • Communicate, articulate or make public the conflicts that arise within the framework of the association's activities in the assemblies or in internal communication itself.
  • Submit disputes that arise due to the functioning of the association to mediation.
article 08

These are causes for being removed from the association:

  • That the interested person decides it, and must communicate their decision in writing to the Board of Directors.
  • Failure to pay the fixed fees or other established forms of payment.
  • Failure to fulfill statutory obligations.
  • Repeated behaviors that violate the code of Desirable Practices.

Chapter III. The General Assembly

article 09
  1. The General Assembly is the sovereign body of the association; the membership forms part of it by its own right and is inalienable.
  2. The membership of the association, gathered in a legally constituted General Assembly, decides by unanimity the matters that are within the Assembly's competence.
  3. All membership is subject to the agreements of the General Assembly, including those who are absent, those who disagree, and those who are present who abstained from voting.
article 10

The General Assembly has the following powers:

  • Approve the management of the governing body, the budget and the annual accounts.
  • Elect and remove those who form part of the governing body and control its activity.
  • Modify the statutes to include diversities.
  • Agree on the form and amount of contributions to the financing of the association or the payment of its expenses, including contributions to the association's assets.
  • Agree on the transformation, merger, division or dissolution of the association.
  • Agree on admission to and withdrawal from federations or confederations.
  • Request the declaration of public utility.
  • Approve the internal regulations and their modifications.
  • Know the requests presented by associated persons, and also admissions and withdrawals for a reason different from definitive separation.
  • Ratify, if applicable, the disciplinary withdrawal and other sanctions imposed by the Board of Directors for very serious offenses.
  • Resolve issues that are not expressly attributed to any other body of the association.
article 11
  1. The General Assembly meets in ordinary session at least once a year, within six months following the date of closing of the fiscal year.
  2. The governing body may convene the General Assembly on an extraordinary basis whenever it deems it convenient, and must do so when requested by 8% of the membership; in this case, the Assembly must take place within seven days from the request.
article 12

Call and operation of the General Assembly

  1. The General Assembly is convened by the governing body by means of a call that must contain, at minimum, the agenda, the place, the date and the time of the meeting.
  2. The call must be communicated fifteen days before the date of the meeting, individually and by means of a written notice addressed to the postal address, the email address or other telematic means of communication that are identified and updated for the membership's contacts.
  3. The meetings may be carried out by videoconference or other means of communication, provided that the identification of those attending, continuity of communication, the possibility of intervening in deliberation and the casting of votes are guaranteed. In this case, the meeting is understood to be held where the person presiding is located.
  4. The meetings of the General Assembly are chaired by the person in charge of the Presidency of the association. If they are not present, they are to be replaced, successively, by the person in charge of the Vice-Presidency or by whoever is a board member by unanimous decision of the rest of the membership present at the meeting. The person in charge of the Secretariat is whoever holds the same position on the Board of Directors.
  5. The Secretariat drafts the minutes of each meeting, which must be signed together with the Presidency, in which an extract of the deliberations, the text of the agreements adopted, the numerical result of the votes and the list of attendees must appear.
  6. At the beginning of each General Assembly meeting, the minutes of the previous session are read so that they can be approved or amended. Five days before, in any case, the minutes and any other documentation must be available to the membership at the social premises.
article 13

Operation of the General Assembly

  1. The General Assembly is validly constituted regardless of the number of people present or represented.
  2. 8% of the membership may request the governing body to include one or more matters on the agenda. If the Assembly has already been convened, they may do so within the first third of the period between the receipt of the call and the date on which this body is to meet. The Assembly may only adopt agreements regarding the points included in the agenda, unless it has been constituted universally or the agreements refer to the calling of a new General Assembly.
article 14

Adoption of agreements

  1. In the meetings of the General Assembly, one vote corresponds to each member of the association.
  2. Agreements are adopted unanimously by the votes of members present or represented.
  3. Agreements may be adopted without a meeting on an exceptional basis —at the request of the Presidency of the association, of two thirds of the members of the Board of Directors or of 8% of the membership— by issuing the vote by postal correspondence, telematic communication or any other means, provided that the rights to information and vote are guaranteed, that receipt of the vote is recorded and that its authenticity is ensured. The agreement is understood to be adopted at the place of domicile of the legal person and on the date of receipt of the last of the validly issued votes.
  4. To adopt agreements on modifying the statutes, dissolving the association, forming a federation with similar associations or integrating into an existing one, and the disposition or alienation of assets, a unanimous decision of the membership present or represented is required.
  5. In any case, the election of the Board of Directors, if several candidacies are presented, is done by agreement of the membership present or represented.
  6. The candidacies presented formally have the right to a copy of the list of membership and postal addresses and email addresses, provided express authorization has been obtained.

Chapter IV. Ordinary Assembly

article 15

The Ordinary Assembly is a type of assembly that takes place every fifteen days in which binding decisions are made regarding proposals and projects that are underway, and debates are held on issues related to this. Ordinary Assemblies are also a space where the activities of the different commissions can be communicated.

article 16

The Ordinary Assembly has the following powers:

  • Present, share and report on the evolution of the commissions.
  • Show and explain the economic exercises in progress and their quarterly summaries.
  • Address and debate the functions of the association.
  • Collect dissensus.
  • Address space maintenance issues.
article 17

The Ordinary Assembly will take place every two weeks and the time and specific date of the next one will be agreed at the end of each session. The decision taken will be communicated officially to all members through the usual communication channel. Attendance by the membership, except for the Board of Directors or its replacement, is not mandatory, but consultation of the minutes is required in order to be informed of the development of the meeting.

article 18

In exceptional and urgent cases the Board of Directors or 8% of the membership may convene an Extraordinary Assembly with a mediated balance between the membership's capacity to attend and the closest possible date.

Chapter V. The Board of Directors

article 19
  1. The Board of Directors governs, administers and represents the association. This body is composed of the Presidency, the Vice-Presidency, the Secretariat, the Treasury and board members; positions that must be held by different people.
  2. The election of the Board of Directors, who must be part of the membership and of legal age, is made by unanimous vote of the General Assembly. The elected persons take office after accepting the position.
  3. The appointment and removal of the positions must be communicated to the Register of Associations by means of a certificate, issued by the outgoing Secretariat with the approval of the Presidency, which must also include the acceptance of the new Presidency and the new Secretariat.
  4. Those who make up the Board of Directors exercise the position without remuneration.
article 20

Term of office and removal of positions

  1. Those who make up the Board of Directors exercise the position for a period of two years, extendable to four years, without prejudice to another candidacy being elected.
  2. The removal of positions before the regulatory term of their mandate expires may occur due to:
    • Death or declaration of absence.
    • Incapacity or disqualification.
    • Resignation notified to the governing body.
    • Removal agreed by the General Assembly.
    • Any other cause established by law or the statutes.
  3. Vacancies that occur on the Board of Directors must be filled at the first meeting of the General Assembly that takes place. In the meantime, a member of the association may provisionally occupy the vacant position by unanimous agreement of the rest of the membership.
article 21

The Board of Directors has the following powers:

  1. Represent, direct and administer the association in the broadest manner recognized by law; likewise, comply with the decisions taken by the General Assembly, in accordance with the rules, instructions and guidelines that the Assembly establishes.
  2. Take the necessary agreements regarding appearances before public bodies and to exercise all kinds of legal actions and file the pertinent appeals.
  3. Suggest to the General Assembly the defense of the association's interests.
  4. Suggest to the General Assembly the defense of establishing the dues that the members of the association must pay.
  5. Call the general assemblies and ensure that the agreements adopted there are complied with.
  6. Present the balance sheet and the statement of accounts for each fiscal year to the General Assembly for approval, and prepare the budgets for the following fiscal year.
  7. Hire employees the association may have.
  8. Inspect the accounting and ensure that the services function normally.
  9. Establish working groups to achieve the association's purposes in the most efficient and effective way, and authorize the acts these groups plan to carry out.
  10. Appoint members of the Board of Directors who are to be in charge of each working group, at the proposal of the groups themselves.
  11. Carry out the necessary procedures before public bodies, entities and other persons to obtain:
    • Subsidies or other aid.
    • Use of premises or buildings that can become a place of coexistence and communication and also a center of citizen recovery.
  12. Open checking accounts and savings books at any credit or savings institution and dispose of the funds held in such deposit. The disposal of the funds is determined in article 34.
  13. Provisionally resolve any case not provided for in the statutes and report it at the first meeting of the General Assembly.
  14. Any other faculty not specifically attributed to another governing body of the association or expressly delegated to it.
article 22

Meetings of the Board of Directors

  1. The Board of Directors, previously convened by the Presidency or by the person who replaces them, must meet in ordinary session with the periodicity decided by the membership, which in no case may be less than once each quarter.
  2. It must meet in extraordinary session when the Presidency convenes it with that character or if requested by one third of the members that compose it.
  3. The meetings may be carried out by videoconference or other means of communication, provided that the identification of those attending, continuity of communication, the possibility of intervening in deliberation and the casting of votes are guaranteed. In this case, the meeting is understood to be held where the person presiding is located.
article 23

Constitution and adoption of agreements of the Board of Directors

  1. The Board of Directors is validly constituted if it has been convened in advance and there is unanimous quorum of the membership.
  2. Those who make up the Board of Directors are obliged to attend all meetings that are convened, although, for justified reasons, they may be excused. The attendance of the Presidency or the Secretariat or the persons who replace them is always necessary.
  3. The Board of Directors adopts agreements by unanimous vote of those attending.
  4. Agreements may be adopted without a physical meeting on an exceptional basis —at the request of the Presidency of the association or two thirds of the members of the board of directors— by issuing the vote by postal correspondence, telematic communication or any other means, provided that the rights to information and vote are guaranteed, that receipt of the vote is recorded and that its authenticity is ensured. The agreement is understood to be adopted at the place of domicile of the legal person and on the date of receipt of the last of the validly issued votes.
article 24

Delegation of powers

  1. The Board of Directors may delegate some of its powers to one or more commissions or working groups if it has, to do so, the consensus of the rest of the association's membership and of whoever integrates the commission.
  2. It may also appoint, with the same quorum, other agents to carry out the function entrusted to them in the powers it deems appropriate to confer in each case.
  3. The formulation of the accounts and the minutes that must be authorized or approved by the General Assembly are not delegable.
article 25

The agreements of the Board of Directors must be recorded in the minutes book and must be signed by the Secretariat and the Presidency. At the start of each meeting of the Board of Directors, the minutes of the previous session must be read so that they can be approved or corrected, if appropriate.

Chapter VI. The Presidency and the Vice-Presidency

article 26
  1. The functions of the Presidency are as follows:
    • Direct and legally represent the association, by delegation of the General Assembly and the Board of Directors.
    • Preside and direct the debates, both of the General Assembly, Ordinary Assembly and the Board of Directors.
    • Mediate in case of voting for the resolution of a unanimous vote.
    • Establish the call for meetings of the General Assembly and the Board of Directors.
    • Approve the minutes and certificates prepared by the Secretariat of the association.
    • The remaining attributions inherent to the position and those delegated by the General Assembly or the Board of Directors.
  2. The Presidency is replaced, in case of absence or illness, by the Vice-Presidency —if there is one— or by the board member agreed by the Board, in that order.

Chapter VII. The Treasury and the Secretariat

article 27

The Treasury's function is the custody and control of the association's resources, as well as the preparation of the budget, balance sheet and liquidation of accounts. It keeps a cash book. It signs fee receipts and other treasury documents. It pays the invoices approved by the Board of Directors, which must be previously approved by the Presidency, and deposits the surplus in deposits opened at credit or savings institutions. It establishes the fees for Membership Type 1 and Membership Type 2 based on the Association's expenses, as well as the payment dates to be made by the membership. If the monthly fee changes, Treasury must notify the membership at least seven days before payment is made.

article 28

The Secretariat must safeguard the association's documentation, draw up, draft and sign the minutes of the meetings of the General Assembly and the Board of Directors, draft and authorize the certificates that must be issued, and also keep the membership register book.

Chapter VIII. Commissions or Working Groups

article 29

The creation and constitution of any Commission or Working Group must be proposed by the membership of the association who wish to form them, who must inform the Board of Directors and the rest of the members, via the usual internal communication means and public exhibition, to explain the activities they propose to carry out and to open the commission to other participants.

The Board of Directors must take care to analyze the different commissions or working groups; those in charge of the commissions must present quarterly in Ordinary Assembly, at least, a detailed report of their actions.

The association consists of three commissions, with the possibility of expanding the number:

Research and dissemination commission:

  • Articulate administration with services and training spaces.
  • Lead the interlocution with external agents and administrative bodies.
  • Work jointly with the other commissions when they need to issue public statements.
  • Prepare representation and press documents.
  • Articulate collaborative projects between entities.
  • Suggest grants and aid of interest in accordance with the political direction.
  • Study proposals related to mobility, exchange, etc.
  • Promote methodologies of cultural learning and experimentation that strengthen ties with the community and territories.
  • Support research and production.
  • Work for the development of artistic research as a generator of knowledge and experiences.
  • Ensure a critical and dialogic vision regarding the association's actions.

Internal policies and gender commission:

  • Work for the construction of a concrete political line representative of the collective.
  • Development of internal protocols, policies and operating procedures.
  • Review and question the political practices of the association.
  • Make internal practices and methodologies constituent.
  • Encourage incentives for membership participation in constituent processes.
  • Deploy dialectical methodologies in decision-making during unanimous votes.
  • Bring the association's ideas to those who do not have social, temporal or cultural capital.

Workshops commission:

  • Maintenance and review of the condition of the workshops available to the association.
  • Development of internal protocols within each workspace.
  • Assist membership that requests technical help to use the workshop.
  • Specific training on the various materials and tools available to interested membership, as well as the risks they entail.
  • Reconsideration of the uses and arrangement of the spaces in the venue, as well as its internal order.
  • Restocking and acquisition of consumables as well as proposals for new tool acquisitions.
article 30

Any member who does not belong to a commission will have the right to attend and participate actively in its meetings. However, the member who attends without being part of it will have binding voice but not constituent voice when decisions are made in the same Commission or Working Group, which will be taken unanimously.

Chapter IX. The economic regime

article 31

The association's economic resources come from:

  • The fees established by the General Assembly for membership.
  • Official or private subsidies, agreements, contracts or official or private awards related to the political line.
  • Donations, inheritances or legacies.
  • The income from its own assets or other income that may be obtained.
article 32

All membership of the association has the obligation to sustain it economically, through fees, levies or in-kind contributions, in the manner and proportion determined by the General Assembly at the proposal of the Board of Directors.

The General Assembly may establish admission fees, monthly periodic fees —which must be paid by months, quarters or semesters, according to what the Board of Directors decides— and extraordinary fees.

article 33

The fiscal year coincides with the calendar year and closes on December 31.

article 34

Management of checking accounts or savings books

In the checking accounts or savings books opened in credit or savings institutions, the signatures of the Board of Directors must appear. However, the account ownership will be in the name of the ETRESMIL Association.

To dispose of the funds, indistinct signatures are sufficient, of which they must be from the Treasury or the Presidency.

Chapter X. The disciplinary regime

article 35

The governing body may sanction infractions committed by the membership.

The Board of Directors will take into account the code of Desirable Practices for the resolution.

These infractions may be classified as minor, serious and very serious, and the corresponding sanctions may range from a warning to expulsion from the association, according to what the internal regulations establish.

The sanctioning procedure begins ex officio or as a consequence of a complaint or communication. Within ten days, the Board of Directors appoints an instructor, who processes the sanctioning file and proposes the resolution within fifteen days, with prior hearing of the alleged offender. The final resolution, which must be reasoned and approved by two thirds of the membership of the Board of Directors, is adopted by this governing body also within a period of fifteen days.

In cases of sanctions for very serious offenses agreed by the Board of Directors, interested persons may request ratification of the sanction before the first General Assembly that takes place.

Chapter XI. Dissolution

article 36

The association may be dissolved if the General Assembly agrees, convened extraordinarily expressly for this purpose.

article 37
  1. Once dissolution has been agreed, the General Assembly must take the appropriate measures both regarding the destination of the association's assets and rights and the purpose, extinction and liquidation of any pending operation.
  2. The Assembly is empowered to elect a liquidation committee whenever it deems it necessary.
  3. The membership of the association is exempt from personal liability. Their liability is limited to fulfilling the obligations they have voluntarily undertaken.
  4. The net remainder resulting from liquidation must be delivered directly to the public or private non-profit entity that, within the territorial scope of the association's activity, has stood out most in its activity in favor of charitable works.
  5. The liquidation and execution functions of the agreements referred to in the preceding sections of this same article are the responsibility of the Board of Directors if the General Assembly does not confer this mission to a liquidation committee specially appointed for this purpose.
